s.text: (This was what I was imagining at the end of the last Moneybox, when I wrote about GM truly becoming an Internet company.)

But if you look at the PC industry, and the difference between the success of direct-selling Dell and Gateway and the struggles of dealer-centric Compaq and IBM, the idea that those auto manufacturers who stay tied to dealers will flourish seems dubious indeed.

But if you look at the PC industry, and the difference between the success of direct-selling Dell and Gateway and the struggles of dealer-centric Compaq and IBM, the idea that those auto manufacturers who stay tied to dealers will flourish seems dubious indeed.
And it's plausible that a car is such a big purchase that many people are going to be uncomfortable buying one online, sight unseen.
Those laws are in part a product of older concerns about vertical integration, so that they served the function of keeping the auto-makers from selling direct to consumers.
The promise of the Internet, from a business perspective, is the promise of a frictionless economy, in which buyers and sellers are able to meet without mediation.
Those laws are in part a product of older concerns about vertical integration, so that they served the function of keeping the auto-makers from selling direct to consumers.
